prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since our science goals are intimately linked to the IR emission of star-forming galaxies we base our sample selection on the public catalog of the Herschel-PEP coverage of the COSMOS field which we matched to public and private redshift compilations of the COSMOS team, as well as to the multi-wavelength data base of COSMOS. All our galaxies have a well-sampled IR SED out to Herschel-Spire wavelengths which allow us to constrain their bolometric luminosities accurately. Our main aim is to investigate how z~2 galaxies behave with respect to the dense gas (HCN) scaling relations observed in the local universe. We hence use the typical LIR/L'HCN~900 ratio of low-z normal galaxies determined by Gao & Solomon (2004) to predict the HCN-line luminosities of our main-sequence targets. To be conservative, and in keeping with Gao and Solomon (2004), we assume a somewhat higher LIR/HCN ratio for starburst galaxies (in our case main sequence outliers), i.e. LIR/L'HCN=1200. We target CO[2-1] and HCN[3-2] or CO[3-2] and HCN[4-3] which fall into ALMA band 3 for the redshift range of interest to us (1.5<z<2.5). Given the faintness of HCN emission we restrict ourselves to galaxies with line-integrated HCN-fluxes of order 0.2 dex, thereby ensuring that each source may be detected within approx. 1 hour of telescope time. We fix our required rms noise level by requiring that S/N=3 be reached even if a galaxy were to lie on the upper edge of the dispersion (~0.3 dex) of the LIR-L'HCN. For a high-z source with exactly the same IR/HCN ratio as the local average we would thus achieve a very robust detection with S/N=6. We have assumed line widths of 300 km/s for normal galaxies and 400 km/s (corresponding to between 90-150 GHz, depending on the observed frequency of the transition) for starbursts when computing the requires on-source time of a line-integrated detection. We have also assumed thermal excitation of the HCN transitions; the shape of the SLED of the HCN-emission in high-z normal galaxies is a complete unknown. However, there are examples (e.g. Riechers et al. 2010) of luminous high-z galaxies where high-J HCN emission is fully thermally excited so we adopted this as our working hypothesis. For our targets the required rms-values to fullfill the aforementioned detection criteria range from 0.1-0.3 mJy. We have grouped sources with similar expected flux densities and line frequencies into one Science Goal where possible to reduce overheads. A key criterion in defining our candidates for HCN follow-up, was that we could cover the HCN-line and a low-J CO transition with one common tuning. BY detecting both lines simultaneously, we can keep overheads due to tuning and calibration low enough that the average observation time (incl. overheads) per source is ~1.2 hours. Our total observing time request for 8 sources thus amounts to ~9.6 hours. We require the most compact ALMA configuration to maximise our detection probability. In order to (i) ensure a good sampling of the CO-lines which will be detected with such high S/N that a detailed line profile can be measured, and in order to keep sufficient flexibility to detect additional line nearby HCN (e.g. HCO+) we have adopted the 1875.000 MHz( 6274 km/s), 976.563 kHz( 3.268 km/s). If this is not practicable we would modify our spectral setup prior to the actual observations, should they be granted.
see justification provided in Science Goal "J095840_MSx3.1, J095908_SBx38.8"

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The current explanation for the high specific star formation rates (SFR) in typical distant galaxies postulates very high total gas fractions and moderate star formation efficiencies. This is equivalent to assuming a small/moderate dense gas fraction. However, no observation is yet available for dense gas tracers inside normal, main sequence galaxies at high redshifts. We propose to remedy this by obtaining the first HCN detection of a sample of 8 galaxies at 1.5<z<2.5, including 4 main sequence galaxies and 4 objects with higher specific SFRs. This will test whether there is cosmic evolution in the dense gas to bolometric luminosity ratio, or whether a universal SF law for dense gas holds for both local and high-z galaxies. Our observations have been designed to simultaneously detect low-J CO transitions and HCN-emission, which will permit us to determine the dense gas fraction of our targets. These observations will investigate, for the first time, if starburst activity - or, in particular, excess specific SFR w.r.t. the star-forming main sequence - correlates with higher dense gas fractions not only in local galaxies but also at the peak epoch of star-formation activity.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics & Astronomy, Sussex, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Spitzer Science Center, California Institute of Technology
